image.altText: A man stands in front of a large house with his arms held open.

props.synopsis: Despite a surge in interest rates and a jump in loss-making rentals, few landlords are selling up. Experts say it's because negative gearing and the capital gains tax discount protect their investments.

title.children: Mega landlords 'can't lose' as revenue collapse brings negative gearing boon

image.altText: Donald Trump smiles.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump says a prospective peace deal between Russia and Ukraine will likely include "some swapping of territories", as he confirms a plan to meet Vladimir Putin in Alaska.

title.children: Trump says he'll meet with Putin in Alaska next week

image.altText: A woman walks through a destroyed street and protects her head from debris

props.synopsis: The foreign ministers of Australia, Germany, Italy, New Zealand and the United Kingdom say this decision will "risk violating international humanitarian law".

title.children: Australia strongly rejects Israel's plan to seize Gaza City

image.altText: A video on TikTok shows a large group of men dressed in black, carrying placards and flags, and chanting.

props.synopsis: Premier Jacinta Allan says "Nazis", "goons" will not be tolerated after about 100 people marched through Melbourne dressed in black and chanting.

title.children: 'We're not afraid of these goons': Premier reacts after Melbourne 'Nazi' march

image.altText: A small bright green airplane in a hanger.

props.synopsis: It's been a week since Tasmanian couple Gregory Vaughan and Kim Worner along with their dog Molly, stepped into a small green plane and flew away without a trace.

title.children: Disappearance of couple and dog begs question of how a plane can go missing in 2025

image.altText: Tall pine trees in front of a snow-capped mountain range.

props.synopsis: National Parks are being forced to stay open despite operating on a "bare-bones" crew after cuts to staff and funding. Rangers say they can't sustain it.

title.children: Once 'America's best idea', National Parks are reaching their breaking point

image.altText: Man leaning on a back of a car with One Piece logo on his left.

props.synopsis: Young Indonesians dissatisfied with the government are flying a flag from the popular anime One Piece ahead of the country's 80th independence day.

title.children: A popular Japanese anime flag has become a symbol of resistance

image.altText: Matt Wright pic (1)

props.synopsis: Bugged phone calls, allegations of lies and planned destruction of evidence — revelations from the first week of the criminal trial against Outback Wrangler Matt Wright.

title.children: Outback Wrangler's bugged midnight phone call at centre of charge

image.altText: Dr Karl softly gazes at the camera while sat at a table outside with a milkshake in a metal cup in front of him.

props.synopsis: How much do you actually know about Dr Karl Kruszelnicki? With the veteran science broadcaster taking his triple j show out of the studio for the first time, we find out his origin story — and so much more.

title.children: The weirdest question Dr Karl has ever been asked

image.altText: A St Kilda AFL player sits on the shoulders of a Richmond defender as he grabs the ball while other players watch.

props.synopsis: Richmond plays St Kilda to kick off Saturday football, before Brisbane takes on its 2024 grand final opponent Sydney. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Tigers face Saints before finals contenders try to avoid slip-ups

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: We are underway at the MCG

image.altText: A woman and teenage boy smile while in a side hug

props.synopsis: Byron Waller is smashing records and while the milestone is great, he hopes to use the limelight to raise awareness for other things.

title.children: Fifteen-year-old hopes to break record as youngest pilot to fly around world

image.altText: Microbat sitting on rock

props.synopsis: A threatened species of bat has been found living just metres from homes in NSW, surprising scientists who did not think it would move into urban environments.

title.children: Discovery of bat the size of 20c coin sparks hope for recovery

image.altText: Anthony Albanese holds a press conference with New Zealand prime minister Christopher Luxon.

props.synopsis: The two leaders are also expected to discuss their positions on the humanitarian crisis in Gaza and recognising Palestinian statehood.

title.children: Defence and trade top of the agenda for PM's meeting in New Zealand

image.altText: a woman and a man standing on a street on a sunny day

props.synopsis: Premier Rockliff's recent move to appoint an independent to the prominent position has been hailed by some as a show of collaboration across the chamber, but others question whether it's a move to neutralise an opposing voice during a time of political turmoil.

title.children: Independent MLC appointed as Leader for the Government in Tasmania's upper house

image.altText: James Tomkins drapped in the Australian flag, in front of the Olympic rings, looking over his right shoulder

props.synopsis: A Victorian study has found elite male rowers are seven times more likely to develop atrial fibrillation, a common heart rhythm disorder associated with increased risk of stroke.

title.children: Elite male rowers seven times more likely to develop heart disorder, study finds

image.altText: Pelicans catching fish in their beaks

props.synopsis: A new eco-friendly take on an iconic Central Coast tourist attraction sees a 100 per cent spike in visitor numbers.

title.children: Pelican attraction's new focus on saving hurt birds doubles visitors

image.altText: Two people examine a wide fossil bed surrounded by dry, rocky terrain.

props.synopsis: Station owners hosted scientists for decades at Nilpena, in South Australia, where excavations uncovered rare Ediacaran fossils, before selling the land to secure its future as a national park.

title.children: Sale of fossil-rich Nilpena cattle station protects ancient treasures

image.altText: Irukandji jellyfish species Malo bella photographed on the Ningaloo Reef as part of a research project.

props.synopsis: An "unusual" jellyfish sting outside of the wet season at Broome's Cable Beach prompts reminders about the year-round dangers posed by these tiny sea creatures.

title.children: How common are Irukandji jellyfish and what are the risks?

image.altText: An woman with half of her face covered with a snood wearing an Adidas puffer jacket leaves court.

props.synopsis: Jennifer Chin was found guilty of stabbing her daughter's clandestine boyfriend in what even the judge called an "unusual" case. Here's how it unfolded.

title.children: How a secret boyfriend was stabbed amid a 'whirlwind of panic'

image.altText: Graphic of Queensland premier David Crisafulli with business receipts.

props.synopsis: Politicians have private business, but that business is sometimes thrust into the public arena, raising questions about how transparent they're required to be, writes Liam Walsh.

title.children: How Qld's premier went from property flipper to secret business trouble

image.altText: A young woman with long black hair holds a baby girl in her arms standing in a kitchen

props.synopsis: Women who have spent years navigating the health system seeking care for extreme pain say they are frustrated at the slow pace of a government inquiry into the issue.

title.children: 'It's not right': Frustration as Australian-first women's pain inquiry in limbo

image.altText: Electricians place solar panels on roof

props.synopsis: As Australia's energy transition hits turbulence, a quiet but fundamental shift is underway.

title.children: Can Australia's staggering 'small-scale flex' save our energy future?

image.altText: A hand holds a black sandal with a woven upper.

props.synopsis: Adidas could face legal action as Mexican authorities accuse the brand of copying traditional huarache sandals.

title.children: Mexico seeks legal action after Adidas launches sandals with traditional style

image.altText: A photo of Tsutomu Yamaguchi. He has short white hair, brown eyes, and is wearing a black collared shirt.

props.synopsis: There are not many people that have survived a nuclear attack. Tsutomu Yamaguchi is the only person that officially survived two.

title.children: 'It was my fate to keep on living': How one man survived two nuclear attacks

image.altText: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speaks during a press conference in Jerusalem.

props.synopsis: The debate in the Israeli media over Benjamin Netanyahu's plans to occupy Gaza have barely mentioned the fate of the two million people who live there.

title.children: Israel's plan is unfolding at a time leaders don't care about global criticism

image.altText: Head and shoulders portrait of Gareth Ward

props.synopsis: Well before Gareth Ward's conviction for serious sex crimes, he was one of the most powerful politicians in NSW. His political career unravelled until he stood alone and, finally, in the dock.

title.children: Once a Liberal rising star, Gareth Ward is now behind bars

image.altText: A photo of a pencil drawing of Nimrod Cohen. He is young, has dark hair, a short beard and moustache.

props.synopsis: Nimrod Cohen was taken hostage on October 7, 2023, when Hamas launched its deadly attacks on Israel. His family fears he will become collateral if the international community does not put more pressure on Israel to end the war in Gaza.

title.children: Father of Israeli hostage calls for Palestinian recognition

image.altText: Kathleen Folbigg thanks her supporters in a video she released after being pardoned for wrongful conviction

props.synopsis: Experts are calling for more transparency in the way compensation is calculated for people who are wrongfully imprisoned, after a $2 million payment offered to Kathleen Folbigg was slammed as "totally inadequate".

title.children: 'Can you put a number on it?' The price of wrongful imprisonment

image.altText: Inside the La Trobe Reading Room at the State Library Victoria.

props.synopsis: Are we really comfortable with trading away one of the few financial benefits Australian creatives have left?

title.children: We can't throw Australian creatives and their work into the maws of Big Tech

image.altText: two people hang gliding on a clear day.

props.synopsis: High above the Scenic Rim, Lisa Bradley soars. She's one of the few hang-gliding instructors left in Australia. But her journey to the skies began on the ground, when she was hit by a car.

title.children: Hit by a car, Lisa could barely walk, now she teaches people to fly

image.altText: A person with short, red hair and striped blue and red long sleeved top sits under blue moody lights looking down at camera

props.synopsis: For generations of musicians, there was a simple recipe for success: pack your bags and move to the west but those markets are being challenged by the growing prestige and influence of the music business in Asia.

title.children: How Asia is changing the classic Aussie band origin story

image.altText: Woman with short bright blue hair, and glasses sits smiling, a framed photo portrait of her hangs in the background.

props.synopsis: Ballarat artists share their story with the community, sparking positive conversations about disability and inspiring others to be unapologetically themselves.

title.children: Disability pride is about not having to 'apologise over and over'

image.altText: Paintings showing blurred painting referencing football coverage.

props.synopsis: What does it take to become a working artist who can live and breathe a compulsion to create while making a steady income? The 2025 Hatched showcase has the answers.

title.children: In a makeshift gallery, the nation's top art graduates excite the senses

image.altText: smoke billows out from rubble after the 9/11 attacks

props.synopsis: The new identifications were made through now-improved DNA testing of minute remains found more than 20 years ago amid the World Trade Center's wreckage, the city medical examiner's office says.

title.children: More September 11 victims' remains identified 24 years later
